column1:
RISC-V ISM vol 1 (unpriv. ISA), 20191213

CV32E40P doc rev 46711ac
column5:
Debug mode can be entered by executing the EBREAK or C.EBREAK instruction when dcsr.ebreakm = 1
cause = 1
column6:
Add EBREAK or/and C.EBREAK to arbitrary code
Verify that:
Core switches into debug mode.
Current PC must be saved to DPC
Cause of debug must be saved to DCSR (cause=1)
PC is updated to value on dm_haltaddr_i input
Core starts executing debug cod

Ensure exception routine is not enterred

column1:

CV32E40P doc rev 46711ac
column3: Enter ebreak exception during single stepping
column5: Enter ebreak exception routine when calling EBREAK or C.EBREAK when dcsr.ebreakm == 0.
column6:
Add EBREAK or/and C.EBREAK to arbitrary single stepping code
Verify that:
Core switches into debug mode.
PC of EBREAK instruction must be saved to DPC
Cause of debug must be saved to DCSR (cause=1)
PC is updated to value on dm_haltaddr_i input
Core starts executing debug code
Ensure exception routine is not entered

column5:
Debug mode can be entered by asserting the external signal debug_req_i
cause is set to = 3 (also see verification goal)
column6:
Assert debug_req_i while executing arbitrary code
Verify that:
Core switches into debug mode.
Current PC must be saved to DPC
Cause of debug must be saved to DCSR (cause=debugger(0x3))
PC is updated to value on dm_haltaddr_i input
Core starts executing debug code

column1:
CV32E40P doc rev 46711ac

RISCV-V External Debug Support Version 0.13.2
column5:
The CV32E40P contains a trigger module with a single trigger register capable of triggering on instruction address match.
Write '1' to tdata1[2] to enable matching
Write breakpoint addr to tdata2 register
cause = 2
column6:
Verify that core enters debug mode when the trigger matches on instruction address. NB! According to spec, the tdataN registers can only be written from debug mode, as m-mode writes are ignored.

Enter debug mode by any of the above methods.
Write (randomized) breakpoint addr to tdata2 and enable breakpoint in tdata1[2]
Exit debug mode (dret instruction)
Verify that core enters debug mode on breakpoint addr
Current PC is saved to DPC
Cause of debug must be saved to DCSR (cause=2)
PC is updated to value on dm_haltaddr_i input
Core starts executing debug code

column1:
CV32E40P doc rev 46711ac

RISCV-V External Debug Support Version 0.13.2
column5: When trigger module is disabled, no trigger should fire even though the PC matches the address in tdata2.
column6:
Enter debug mode by any of the above methods.
Write (randomized) breakpoint addr to tdata2 and disable breakpoint in tdata1[2]
Exit debug mode (dret instruction)
Verify that core does not enter debug mode on breakpoint addr

column5: If an exception occurs during debug mode, the PC should be set to the dm_exception_addr_i input without changing the status registers
column6:
Bring core into debug mode, generate all exception types and observe that the PC jumps to the address given by dm_exception_addr_i. Observe no change in status registers
According to specification, the cf32e40p supports the following types of exceptions:
Illegal instruction (2)
Breakpoint (3)
Environment call from M-mode (ECALL) (11)

column5: Accessing the core debug registers - DCSR, DPC and DSCRATCH0/1 while NOT in debug mode causes an illegal instruction
column6: Access all debug registers in M-mode and observe that illegal instruction exception is triggered.

column5: Accessing the trigger module registers - tselect, tdata1/2/3 are readable from M-mode, but not writeable.
column6:
Access all trigger module registers in M-mode and observe writes have no effects and reads should reflect register content.

Access registers from D-mode and observe full R/W access.

column5: While in debug mode and executing from the program buffer, all interrupts are masked.
column6:
Enable interrupts (setting mstatus.mie field and mie register).
Bring core into debug mode and start executing from program buffer.
Generate interrupts while in debug mode and ensure they are masked.

column5: While in debug mode and executing from the program buffer, exceptions don’t update any registers but they DO end execution of PB (TBD: goes back to M-mode or restarts in debug(?)) [PZ] this is redundnant with dm_exception_addr_i (on line 10 & 11)
column6: Bring core into debug mode and start executing from program buffer. Make sure PB includes code that will hit an exception. Make sure core doesn’t update any registers, and jumps out of debug mode into M-mode

column5: While in debug mode and executing from the program buffer, no action is taken on any trigger match.
column6: Bring core into debug and enable a trigger on the PC (pointing to the debug program buffer). Continue execution in debug, and observe that no action is taken when the trigger matches.

column5:
Spec:Counters may be stopped, depending on stopcount in dscr
For CV32E40P, stopcount not implemented, counters are not stopped during debug.
column6:
N/A for CV32E40P : need Arjan/Davide to sign-off on this.

[PZ] We will need a test to ensure counters do not stop couting in debug mode. We cannot disable counters as stopcount is not implemented.

column5: Timers may be stopped, depending on stoptime in dcsr
column6: N/A for CV32E40P : need Arjan/Davide to sign-off on this.  [PZ] I confirm that this is not needed on CV32E40P. There is no timer in CV32E40P.

column5: In debug, the WFI instruction acts as a NOP instruction
column6: Bring core into debug mode. Ensure that an WFI instruction will be executed from the program buffer. Ensure that the WFI will act as a nop, not waiting for an interrupt to occur.

column5: An ebreak instruction during debug shall result in relaunching the debugger entry code by setting the PC to the halt_addr_i and will not change any CSR in doing this.
column6: Bring hart into debug mode and start executing from the Program Buffer. Make sure the PB code includes an ebreak instruction. When the ebreak is executed, the hart must halt and not update dpc or dcsr. Ensure relaunch of debugger entry

column5: Completing program buffer execution is considered output for the purpose of the fence instruction.
column6: TBD - need to understand the fence instruction in cv32e40p. Is "completing program buffer execution" the same as executing dret? [PZ] waiting for more clarity from RISCV Foundation debug task group (see https://lists.riscv.org/g/tech-debug/topic/clarification_request/75725318?p=,,,20,0,0,0::recentpostdate%2Fsticky,,,20,2,0,75725318 )
column10: Fence and fence.i executed during debug mode in DTC "debug_test"

column5: All control transfer instructions may act as illegal instructions if destination is within program buffer. If one does, all must.
column6: N/A for CV32E40P : need Arjan/Davide to sign-off on this. [PZ] This is not supported and it is mentioned in the CV32E40P debug spec. No verification needed to prove nor dis-prove this behavior

column5: All control transfer instructions may as illegal instructions if destination is outside the program buffer. If one does, all must.
column6: N/A for CV32E40P : need Arjan/Davide to sign-off on this. [PZ] This is not supported and it is mentioned in the CV32E40P debug spec. No verification needed to prove nor dis-prove this behavior

column5: Instructions that depend on the PC may act as illegal instructions
column6: N/A for CV32E40P : need Arjan/Davide to sign-off on this. [PZ] This is not supported and it is mentioned in the CV32E40P debug spec. No verification needed to prove nor dis-prove this behavior

column5: Effective XLEN = DXLEN
column6:
CV32E40P XLEN=1 (32 bits).  DXLEN is defined as the widest supported XLEN. For now, this will be 1 (32 bits). Check XLEN M- and D-mode
Mike: what exactly would a testcase actually do to check this?
ØK: As discussed in the meeting 02.July, this is probably a SW/DM problem. Leaving it here for reference.

N/A for CV32E40P (requires A-extention) : need Arjan/Davide to sign-off on this. [PZ] This is not a test but a warning or assumption that debug entry should not occur between a lr and sc instruction pair. Moreover, CV32E40P does not support A-extension

column5: If debug_req_i is asserted while waiting for interrupt (core_sleep_o = 1), WFI instruction must complete (core_sleep_o -> 0) and hart enters debug mode.
column6: Insert WFI instruction into arbitrary code. While the hart is waiting for an interrupt, request debug mode. The hart must stop waiting for interrupt and enter debug mode. WFI at trigger will be converted to a NOP and should be a dedicated test. See #pz_ref2 in this sheet below

column5: By setting step in dcsr[2] before resuming execution, a debugger can cause the hart to execute a single instructin before re-entering debug mode.
column6: Bring the hart into debug mode. Set the step bit in dcsr[2] and then resume execution. Observe that the hart runs a single instruction and the goes back to debug mode.

column5:
If the instruction being fetched or executed in a single step casues an exception, debug mode is entered immediately after the PC is changed to the exception handler and registers tval and cause are updated.

Note: CV32E40P does not support tval (this should be supported in future cores)
column6:
Perform a single step. Make sure the instruction executed in the step will cause an exception. PC must jump to the exception handler address and update tval and cause and then immediately enter debug mode.

Check tval==0, then on future cores, when implemented, it will fail and require a test update

column5: If the instruction being fetched or executed in a single step causes a trigger, debug mode is entered immediately after the trigger fired. Cause is set to 2 instead of 4
column6: Set up the trigger module to match on instruction address. Set up single stepping such that the match address will be executed in a step. The trigger module must fire during the step, and debug mode entered with cause = 2 to identify that the trigger was fired. (#1)

column5: If the intruction executed in the single step results in a PC that will cause an exception, the exception will not execute until the next time the hart resumes.
column6: Make sure that an instruction in the instruction memory will generate a PC that causes an exception. Set up single stepping and make sure to step through this specific instruction. Hart must go back to debug mode after stepping, and the exception must not start executing until the next time the hart resumes (either single step or exit debug mode)

column5: If the intruction executed in the single step results in a PC that will cause a trigger event, the trigger event will not take place until the instruction is executed.
column6:
This can be verified in the same steps as marked with (#1).
Mike: this may be difficult to accurately predict in the ISS.  This is good input for the Imperas team.

column5: If the single step instruction is WFI, it must be treated as a nop instead of stalling and waiting for interrupt. [PZ] #pz_ref2
column6: Perform a single step where the instruction to be executed is a WFI instruction. The hart must not wait for interrupt, but treat the instruction as as NOP and re-enter debug after finishing the step.

column5: When the hart comes out of reset, it must immediately enter debug mode without executing any instructions if the halt signal or debug_req_i is asserted.
column6: Assert the core reset AND the debug_req_i signal. The hart must not execute any instructions, but immediately enter debug mode.

column5: Executing dret while NOT in debug mode will cause an illegal instruction exception.
column6:
Insert dret into arbitrary code running in m-mode, observe that the illegal insctruction exception is thrown.
Can be tested in the same test as for debug entry

column5:
Executing dret while in debug mode will restore PC to the value in dpc and exit debug mode. (privilege level will be restored to the value in dcsr).
Note: CV32E40P only supports machine mode.
column6:
Bring hart into debug mode. Execute a dret instruction and observe that the hart resumes executing from the correct address as given by dpc. 
Can be tested in the same test as for debug entry.

column5:
To enable semihosting, a special instruction sequence is needed as there is only a single EBREAK instruction available.

slli x0, x0, 0x1f # Entry NOP
ebreak # Break to debugger
srai x0, x0, 7 # NOP encoding the semihosting call number 7

[PZ] This is a software convention and need not be tested in verification. As long as the above instructions work in general, then no need for dedicated semihosting testing.
column6: If all points above passes, there should be nothing to verify here. Semihosting will be handled from SW.

column5: If the trigger matches on an illegal instruction, PC must be set to the exception handler prior to entering debug mode.
column6: Set up the trigger to match on an address containing an illegal instruction. When the trigger fires, ensure that cause=0x2(trigger) and that PC is set to the exception handler before entering debug mode.
column10: With timing=0 the core will not attempt to execute instruction at trigger address
With timing=0 the core will not attempt to execute instruction at trigger address

column5: If the trigger matches on an illegal instruction, PC must be set to the exception handler prior to entering debug mode.
column6:
Set up the trigger to match on an address containing an illegal instruction. 
Set up single stepping such that the match address will be executed in the next step.
When the trigger fires, ensure that cause=0x2(trigger) and that PC is set to the exception handler before entering debug mode.
column10: With timing=0 the core will not attempt to execute instruction at trigger address
With timing=0 the core will not attempt to execute instruction at trigger address

column1:
RISC-V External Debug Support Version 0.13.2
CV32E40P doc rev 46711ac
column5: While single stepping, interrupts may be enabled or disabled using the dcsr.stepie bit.
column6: Set up single stepping. Ensure interrupt is asserted while performing a step. Ensure that the interrupt is taken when dcsr.stepie = 1, and not taken when dcsr.stepie = 0.
Have debug_req_i and interrupt asserted on same clock cycle. Ensure debugger entered with PC reflecting normal PC thread (not the interrupt exception address)

column5: All RISCV code should run in debug mode as well as M mode
column6: [PZ] Run RISCV compliance tests all in debug mode

[PZ] assert debug_req and interrupt at the same time as trigger is matching an address (with trigger enabled) and the instruction being 1) illegal instruction 2) exception call (e.g. ebreak with ebreakm==0) 3) branch 4) multicycle instruction (e.g. mulh)
[PZ] Add coverage to ensure debug_req asserted on every FSM state

[PZ] Have trigger address match an instruction that has an illegal instruction (both in normal and single step mode). Ensure debug is enterred with cause set to trigger and PC is set to exception handler prior to debug entry
column10: Not possible with timing=0, core will not execute instruction at match address before entering debug mode.

column5: If a debug_req_i is asserted when an illegal instructions is being executed, the address of the trap handler must be stored to dpc instead of the address of the illegal instruction

Several causes exist for entering debug, the priority is as follows:
1: Trigger match
2: Ebreak
3: Reset halt request
4: Halt request
5: Single step
column6: Ensure combinations of reasons exist simultaneously, and observer that the correct cause is stored to dcsr.
column10: Partly covered in DTC "debug_test" and "debug_test_trigger", the rest will be covered by corev_rand_debug_ebreak and corev_rand_debug_single_step

CG: uvm_pkg.uvm_test_top.env.cov_model.debug_covg.debug_causes
        (.trig_vs_ebreak, trig_vs_cebreak, trig_vs_dbg_req, trig_vs_step
          ebreak_vs_req, cebreak_vs_req, ebreak_vs_step, cebreak_vs_step, dbg_req_vs_step)

column5: When the reset signal is deasserted, but before the fetch_enable_i signal is active, the internal clock of the core is gated. An issue in the cv32e40p repo describes a scenario where a short pulse of debug_req_i could be missed due to the clock gating.
column6: Assert short (1 cycle) debug_req_i randomly after reset, before the core starts executing. Observe that the core enters debug mode without executing any instructions prior to entry.
